document.docTitle: Anicius grisae Guerrero-Fuentes & Francke 2019, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic revision of Anicius Chamberlin, 1925 (Araneae: Salticidae), with five new species of jumping spiders from Mexico

Etymology. The specific name, a noun in genitive, is dedicated to acarologist Griselda Montiel Parra, nicknamed “Gris”, who helped collect the holotype .

Diagnosis. Live specimens have a metallic green luster, and differ from other
Anicius
species in the number of lateral abdominal spots, two dark spots and two white spots ( Figs 9–10 ),
A. grisae
has four pairs of spots ( Fig 10 ). The male palp resembles
A. cielito
but
A. grisae
differs from the other
Anicius
species by the presence of a keel in the promargin of the embolus ( Fig 76 ), TL bilobed with two marginal crests and the bulb is kidney-shaped ( Figs 68 , 76 ). Females of
A. grisae
resembles
A. cielito
in leg I color pattern, but differs from it in the general shape of the epigyne,
A. grisae
has the CD with the convergent-divergent pattern ( Fig 86 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 18–23. Typical habitats where the species of
Anicius
. 18 cloud forest in type locality of
A. cielito
sp. nov.
; 19 forest with oaks (Michoacán), habitat of
A. dolius
; 20 fragmented oak forest (Michoacán), habitat of
A. dolius
; 21 pine-oak forest, type locality of
A. faunus
sp. nov.
; 22 oak-pine forest, type locality of
A. grisae
sp. nov.
; 23 fragmented oak forest in the type locality of
A. maddisoni
sp. nov.

FIGURES 24–29.
Anicius dolius
24–26 male (CNAN-Ar010558) (24 dorsal, 25 ventral, 26 lateral). 27–29 female (CNAN- Ar01561) (27 dorsal, 28 ventral, 29 lateral). Scale bars: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. Male ( holotype CNAN-T 01096). Total length: 3.50. Prosoma: 1.70 long, 1.20 wide, 0.70 high. Opisthosoma: 1.80 long. Eye field: 0.70 long, anterior width 0.90, posterior width 0.90. Cheliceral length 0.50. Length of leg segments: I 1.10 + 0.70 + 1.00 + 0.70 + 0.45 = 3.95; II 0.75 + 0.50 + 0.60 + 0.40 + 0.35 = 2.60; III 0.80 + 0.40 + 0.55 + 0.40 + 0.30 = 2.45; IV 0.80 + 0.15 + 0.75 + 0.60 + 0.35 = 2.95. Leg spination: I: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-1; Pt 0-1-0; Tb v 2-2 -2; Mt v 0-2-
2. II
: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-1; Tb v 1-1 -2; Mt v 0-1-
2. III
: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-2, r 0-0-1; Tb v 0-0-2, p 0-1-0, r 0-1-0; Mt p 0-0-1, r 0-0-
1. IV
: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-1, r 0-0-1; Tb v 0-0-2, p 0-0-1, r 0-0-1; Mt p 0-0-1, r 0-0-1. Body coloration: specimens in alcohol turn to a brownish yellow color with metallic scales. Carapace dark brown, with a white band of setae around the lateral margins of the carapace and across the clypeus ( Figs 48, 50 ), abdominal white bands followed by four pairs of spots, first and third white, second and fourth darker ( Fig. 9 ). Chelicera: as described for the genus ( Fig. 15 ). Legs: I dark brown, stouter and longer than the other legs; II–IV thin and pale-yellow. Opisthosoma: ventrally with a very wide dark colored band and two thin submedian longitudinal stripes ( Fig. 49 ). Palp: dark brown; embolus short and stout and curved less than 75°, but more than 70° ( Fig. 76 ); TL with two triangular crest as long as wide, the base of the bulb more extended to the retromarginal side than the rest of the bulb ( Figs 68, 69 , 76 ); RTA like a flattened spine.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 30–35.
Anicius chiapanecus
sp. nov.
30–32 holotype male (MCZ 49716) (30 dorsal, 31 ventral, 32 lateral). 33–35 female (MCZ 49720) (33 dorsal, 34 ventral, 35 lateral). Scale bars: 1 mm.

FIGURES 36–41.
Anicius cielito
sp. nov.
36–38 holotype male (CNAN-T01098) (36 dorsal, 37 ventral, 38 lateral). 39–41 paratype female (CNAN-T01099) (39 dorsal, 40 ventral, 41 lateral). Scale bars: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Female ( paratype CNAN-T 1097). Total length: 3.70. Prosoma: 1.50 long, 1.50 wide. 0.70 high. Opisthosoma: 2.20 long. Eye field: 0.80 long, anterior width 1.00, posterior width 1.00. Cheliceral length 0.40. Length of leg segments: I 1.00 + 0.60 + 0.80 + 0.50 + 0.30 = 3.20; II 0.80 + 0.40 + 0.50 + 0.30 + 0.30 = 3.25; III 0.70 + 0.40 + 0.50 + 0.40 + 0.30 = 2.30; IV 1.00 + 0.50 + 0.70 + 0.60 + 0.40 = 2.30. Leg spination: I: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-2; Tb v 2-2 -2; Mt v 0-2-
2. II
: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-1; Tb v 1-1 -2, p 0-0-1; Mt v 0-2-2, p 0-0-1, r 0-0-
1. III
: Fm d 1-1-1, p 0-0-1; Mt p 0-0-2, r 0-0-
2. IV
: Fm d 1-1-1; Mt p 0-0-1, r 0-0-1. Differences with the male: Legs: leg I stouter and longer than the others, brown with tarsus and metatarsus yellow; II–IV thin and pale-yellow ( Fig. 10 ). Palp: yellow. Epigyne: simple, CD with the convergent-divergent pattern ( Figs 86–87 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 36–41.
Anicius cielito
sp. nov.
36–38 holotype male (CNAN-T01098) (36 dorsal, 37 ventral, 38 lateral). 39–41 paratype female (CNAN-T01099) (39 dorsal, 40 ventral, 41 lateral). Scale bars: 1 mm.

FIGURES 42–47.
Anicius faunus
sp. nov.
42–44 holotype male (CNAN-T01041) (42 dorsal, 43 ventral, 44 lateral). 45–47 paratype female (CNAN-T01042) (45 dorsal, 46 ventral, 47 lateral). Scale bars: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Males (n = 14). Total length: 3.40–4.00. Prosoma: 1.70–2.00 long, 1.00–1.70 wide. 0.60–0.80 high. Opisthosoma: 1.80–2.10 long, 1.00–1.30 wide. Eye field: 0.70–0.90 long, anterior width 1.00–1.20, posterior width 1.00–1.20. Cheliceral length 0.50–0.70. Females (n = 34) Total length: 3.60–4.00. Prosoma: 1.50–1.80 long, 1.20– 1.40 wide. 0.60–0.70 high. Opisthosoma: 1.90–3.10 long. Eye field: 0.70–0.80 long, anterior width 1.00–1.10, posterior width 1.00–1.10. Cheliceral length 0.40–0.50. Some specimens (n = 4) do not have the medial longitudinal dark band on opisthosoma well-defined, or have just one pair of dark lateral spots (n = 6). Some males have blunt, instead of bicuspid retromarginal tooth (n = 8).

Natural history. Specimens were found during the day in mixed oak-pine forests wandering on trees, between 1,500 to 2,500 m elevation ( Fig. 22 ). This species has a greater abundance of adults during spring and summer; May is the best month to collect adult males and June to collect pregnant females. Five females were collect in June in Oaxaca , three of them, laid egg sacks seven days later, with 11– 13 eggs each. Females showed parental care, stay- ing close to the egg sack and keeping their legs over the egg sac most of the time. After eight weeks, six spiderlings emerged from one of the egg sacks, and they died a few days later. The other two females died two weeks after its recollection and their egg sacks rotted a few days later.
Distribution. Estado de México , Guerrero , Morelos and Oaxaca , Mexico ( Fig. 17 ).
